thread.title: Major hurricane Olaf strengthens, enters Central Pacific
thread.title_full: Major hurricane Olaf strengthens, enters Central Pacific - KPTV - FOX 12

author: Ben Gutierrez
title: Major hurricane Olaf strengthens, enters Central Pacific
text:
HONOLULU (HawaiiNewsNow) - Hurricane Olaf has gained more strength as it entered the Central Pacific basin.
The Central Pacific Hurricane Center said at A 11 p.m. Monday, Olaf's winds had increased to 150 miles per hour, making it a Category 4 hurricane. It was located approximately 1,175 miles east-southeast of the Big Island, or 1,385 miles east-southeast of Honolulu, and was moving toward the west-northwest at 10 miles per hour.
Hurricane force winds extend up to 35 miles outward from the center, and tropical storm force winds extend outward up to 140 miles. Satellite imagery shows a well-defined eye.
Forecasters said some additional strengthening is forecast Tuesday, with fluctuations in intensity Tuesday night and Wednesday. Olaf should turn toward the northwest on Wednesday.
 The current forecast track keeps it well east of Hawaii.
The National Weather Service in Honolulu said if Olaf follows the current forecast track, it will not have any direct impact on the Hawaiian islands; at most, it could turn our trade winds more northerly as it passes to the east. However, weather models indicate that swells from Olaf will begin to reach the east-facing shores of the Big Island by Wednesday. Surf heights will most likely exceed advisory levels and possibly reach warning levels Thursday and Friday. The swell will then slowly diminish over the weekend.
For the other islands the swell will likely arrive by Thursday and linger through the weekend. Surf heights will likely reach advisory levels and possibly low end warning levels during the peak of the swell. Much will depend on the Olaf's size, track and intensity .
Olaf is the 15th tropical cyclone in the basin this year. The previous record was 11.
